awd_titl_txt: Explaining Choice, Persistence, and Attrition of Black Students in Electrical, Computer, and Mechanical Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to identify policies and practices that lead to increased representation, persistence, and graduation as well as attrition for Black students in Electrical Engineering (EE), Computer Engineering (CpE), and Mechanical Engineering (ME) and to make actionable recommendations for policymakers regarding best practices.  The project team is investigating why Black students choose and persist in, or leave ME, EE, and CpE; how their academic pathways vary by gender and institution type; and what policies and practices promote greater retention of Black engineering students. The project will ultimately broaden understanding of the factors that have limited the full participation of Black students in EE, CpE and ME, and identify the positive factors that can attract and retain them in these fields.

This project's intellectual merit is based on a mixed-methods research design that combines the quantitative power of large sample sizes (currently 300,000 students at 17 institutions) available from the Multiple-Institution Database for Investigating Engineering Longitudinal Development (MIDFIELD), the qualitative richness of in-depth student interviews, department and college administrator interviews, and detailed content analysis of institutional policies and contexts at two Historically Black Colleges and Universities and two Predominantly White Institutions. The researchers integrate three theories that have been used in prior work on under-represented minority students: critical race theory, community cultural wealth theory, and intersectionality. This approach will strengthen institutional and individual explanations of engineering student pathways and outcomes.  A comprehensive dissemination plan will ensure that the study results reach a variety of audiences interested in diversifying engineering education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The principal outcomes of our project reveal important findings related to the personal/individual, disciplinary, and institutional influences on the choice of Black students to enroll and persist in or switch out of computer engineering (CpE), electrical engineering (EE), and Mechanical (ME) engineering programs at two historically Black colleges and universities and two predominantly White institutions. Our data sources included in-depth interviews with 79 self-identified Black students who were either currently persisting in or had switched from one of the study majors, pre- and post-interview surveys, environment scans, informant interviews, and longitudinal academic data of earlier cohorts.

All participants reported multiple factors for selecting their majors; the most common were: their abilities in math and science, good job opportunities, high starting salaries, family influences, prestige and challenge of the major, and possibilities of helping others, improving society, and invention. Persisters were more likely than switchers to select a major because of possibilities of helping others or improving society, invention, and using their talents.

Students switched out of their selected majors for a variety of reasons. In roughly decreasing order of occurrence, they were: poor advising, academic challenges, lack of knowledge about the major when they enrolled, financial and personal difficulties, perceived poor fit in the major, and being a first-generation college student. A combination of push and pull factors were cited, such as academic and personal challenges pushing students out of a major and finding a better fit for their interests in another major pulling them into a new one.

Comparing the ratings given by persisters and switchers to specific features of their major programs suggests factors that influence Black students' decisions to stay or switch. Teaching quality ratings of "Excellent" or "Good" were more likely to be given by persisters than switchers. More persisters than switchers were encouraged to continue in their programs by their instructors and peers and felt comfortable about asking questions in class and talking to their instructors one-on-one. Persisters were more likely than switchers to work collaboratively in class and less likely to be discouraged by their instructors from collaborating on homework. Presumably in part because of those differences, persisters were much more likely than switchers to develop a sense of belonging in their departments (84% vs. 25%).

In summary, the students in our study chose their major fields of study and decided whether to persist in or switch out of their majors for a large variety of reasons, some of which can be addressed by administrators, instructors, and advisors. Actionable recommendations for attracting and retaining Black students in engineering from this study include: 1) Before students declare a major, provide orientation on what the students in each major will learn to do, what careers they will be prepared for, and what important social problems they will be equipped to address. Furthermore, continue to provide major exploration and selection support for students who remain uncertain or change their minds after declaring a major. And 2) Provide guidance on effective pedagogy early in the careers of faculty who teach. Among other recommendations, stress the importance of creating a welcoming and inclusive environment, encouraging students to ask them questions in class and to come for help in face-to-face and virtual office hours, and actively engaging them in collaborative learning in class and on homework.

Intellectual Merit

We used an innovative mixed-methods approach that combined the quantitative power of the MIDFIELD database and the NCWIT Student Experience in the Major survey with the qualitative richness of 79 in-depth student interviews to meet the project goal. As of December 2023, the research team had produced 15 peer-reviewed publications and peer-reviewed conference papers, four conference posters and a conference presentation. We also published an instructional video on "How to Use a Card-Sort Activity in Interviews" via Sage Research Methods to further disseminate an effective technique for eliciting authentic narratives.  

Broader Impacts

Our project has produced rich and nuanced portraits of Black students' experiences in engineering. Our innovative mixed-methods approach has helped to broaden understanding of the factors that have limited the full participation of Black students in EE, CpE, and ME, and helped us identify the positive factors that can attract and retain them in these fields. The findings will allow administrators, advisors, and instructors to create more accessible and inclusive pathways to engineering education for Black students, intervene early when students begin to experience academic challenges and before they decide to switch out of their major or leave the institution. Broad impacts will be evidenced by fuller participation of Black students in engineering programs, leading to a more diverse engineering workforce.
